string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on educational measurement. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

Today’s lecture might be a bit challenging for some and a review for others. We are going to unpack a few topics that are essential to the understanding of educational research. To be a good consumer of education research, we need to:

• Understand scale of measurement

• Distinguish different types of frequency distributions

• Apply central tendency (i.e., mode, mean, & median) in context

• Identify measurement validity and reliability

First let’s review a few definitions.

Population refers to the entire group we want to study, understand, and generalize about.

Sample refers to a smaller subset of the population that we will study.

Parameter summarizes a characteristics of the population.

Statistic summarizes a characteristic of the sample.

There are two main types of statistics.

Descriptive statistics summarize and describe the characteristics of a population. There is usually one variable at a time.

For example, a study could just review the test scores of a student population to describe some of the characteristics of this student population.

Inferential statistics provide results that can be generalized to the larger population.

For example, we may compare two instructional interventions and infer which intervention may work better for the whole student population.

What is measurement?

According to McMillian, “measurement can be defined as an appraisal of the amount of something.” The amount of something is typically a set of numbers to indicate different values of a trait, characteristic, or other unit under investigation as a variable.

We use scale of measurement to differentiate variables in research. The nature of differentiation depends on types of variables such as male/female, test scores, types of schools, and so on. Four methods that are referred as scales of measurement are often used to measure variables.

Scales of measurement are used to determine the nature of quantification needed to answer the research question. They are typically classified into four types:

-Nominal

-Ordinal

-Interval

-Ratio

Nominal variables are also called categorical variables. They are given names within a category. There is not magnitude or equal intervals. They cannot be ranked or ordered.

For examples, names, gender, and status are all nominal data. You can see how the data can be collected in a survey from the examples on the slide.

With ordinal scales, we classify persons or things, but also ranks them.

The variables within a list have an order relative to one another but the distance between each may not have the same value.

For example, we can rank the performance of swimming teams by best, very good, and good but the differences between best and very good are not the same as good and very good. Take a look at the examples on the slide, is the difference between disagree and strongly disagree the same as neutral and agree? We can’t say.

Some examples ordinal scales are:

-Baseball standings

-High School Rank

-Opinion scales

Interval data classify persons or things, but also ranks them.

The variables within the list have an order relative to one another and have equal intervals between values. Using test scores for example, the distance between 80 points and 90 points is the same as the distance between 70 points and 60 points. Other examples include SAT scores, IQ scores, and temperature.

Ratio scale Has magnitude and equal intervals between values. Ratio scale has a value of zero that is a meaningful value.

Other examples include height, weight, years of work experiences or education, number of children, income, and temperature. You may see in some cases temperature is either considered an interval or ratio scale because it does have a zero.

In summary, nominal scale variables are used to “name” or label variables such as gender, race, and status.

Ordinal scales lead to information about the “order” of things, such as customer satisfaction survey. Interval scales provide us the order of values and ways to quantify the differences between each one, such as test scores.

Ratio scales have the characteristics of interval scale plus an absolute “zero” point.

Why is it important to learn scale of measurement? From this table you can see when it comes to statistical analysis, we can determine how to calculate the central tendency as mode, median, or mean based on the data type. You will not calculate the mean if the variables are nominal.

We will learn more about central tendency in the next few slides. We will use these terms several times through out the course so it’s important to understand the difference.

In quantitative studies, the data is collected then descriptive statistics are used to better understand the meaning of the numbers.

Descriptive statistics transform a set of numbers into summary indices. We can organize ungrouped data as in the simple frequency table on the left here but this can be cumbersome to list all number.

We can group the data by ranges of scores as indicated in the table on the right. Lower case f stands for frequency.

Another way to organize data is to point out the number and/or percentage of scores by adding a third column, which gives a running total to show the number of participants with a specific score as shown in this table. CF stands for cumulative frequency.

We can show frequency in two-dimensional graphs or charts. In this polygon, we show frequencies on the vertical dimension and the scores or score intervals on the horizontal dimension. The number of students obtaining each score is plotted on the graph, which is also known as frequency polygon.

This way, we can have a quick overview of the frequency distribution from a group of students. Note the frequency is represented by the symbol of f.
In this histogram, you can see the most and least frequently occurring scores in a glance.

Histograms can also become bar graphs.

In a bar chart, the column is usually organized in nominal data such as types of schooling or ordinal data such as ranking.

Many of the computer programs such as Microsoft Excel or Google Sheet provide graph-generating function for you to create frequency graphs.

Although it is nice to have frequency distribution and graphs, it is also important to use a single number to describe a set of scores. The three most commonly used measures of central tendency are mean, median, and mode.

- Mean indicates the arithmetic average of all scores. We use this for Interval or ratio data. We often see an X bar, an x with a bar cross the top to symbolize the mean in many statistical tables. X is the symbol for a given value in a distribution

- Median indicates the middle score in a distribution. This is useful with ordinal data. In this example, 4 is the median.

- Mode indicates a score in a distribution that occurs most often. This is appropriate for nominal data. In this example, 3 is the most commonly occurring number so 3 is the mode.

Let’s move on to a bit more sophisticated way of understanding the distribution.

We know what the central tendency are, mean, median, and mode. Let’s look at measures of variability which gives us a sense of how much variety or how messy the distribution is.

There are three ways that we talk about measures of variability in a distribution. One is range. This is the most primitive measure, useful for ordinal data, and little bit useful for interval and ratio data. This is the distance between the highest and lowest values in the whole distribution. In the example in the table, the range between the number 1 and 9 is 8.

Another measure of variability is called variance. It is a descriptive statistic that describes the amount of variety among all the scores, it looks how far each score has fallen away from the mean of the distribution. The symbol for a variance is sigma square.

Now Standard Deviation is just like variance but in the original units of the distribution. We will talk more about it later so if it’s not entirely clear to you, just click ahead and you can always come back to review. The symbol for standard deviation is the Greek symbol of sigma.

I list the formula here for your reference. You don’t need to remember it. We do not calculate these by hand. Most computer programs can do the calculation for you.
Now let’s look at one example to understand how we analyze numbers. Pretend this is a set of scores from a classroom. How do you make sense of these scores?
We can list all scores from top to bottom, from 99, 98 and all the way to 58. That gives you some information but it didn’t help to make sense of the numbers.

What makes sense is to calculate the average scores, adding them all up and dividing the sum by the number of all numbers you have together.

I can also look at just the numbers at the first row and calculate the mean. The sum of the numbers in the first row is 394 divided by 5 which is 78.8. The symbol x bar, x under the bar, is to represent the mean of 78.8.

Now I am going to take out 59 from the first row since it’s an outlier. I added them up and divided the number by 4. This time I got 83.5, quite an increase in the mean.

AS you recall, the previous mean is 78.8. This indicates if you have an extreme score, it has a pretty big impact on the mean. For that reason, we are trying to talk about average scores.

We sometimes may want to calculate the mode, median, or all three to get an idea of the central tendency of the scores.

Another way of getting a sense of the numbers is to look at how variable they are. Range is one way of talking about variability.

Scores range from 58 to 99 but there’s another term we use to get the idea of variability which is standard deviation. Standard deviation is the average distance of all scores from the means.

To calculate standard deviation you have to do a lot of arithmetic but we usually don’t do it by hand. You can use many tools such as a calculator, a computer program. In this case, I used Excel spreadsheet.

I entered all 25 scores and ask the program to calculate the standard deviation which is 10.39. The average of all these scores from mean which 89 is 10 points. How do I interpret the 10 points, how close they are together and how far they are from mean. We will come back to that just a little bit.

I want to talk about normal distribution curve first. You might have heard this called a Bell curve.

There are standard markers on the curve that we call standard deviation units. We put zero in the middle as the mean. Have one standard deviation unit above the mean, two standard deviation units above the mean, and three standard deviation units above the mean. Then one, two, and three standard deviation units below zero. It’s not the same as a calculated standard deviation that we just talked about.

These are standard deviation markers on the normal curve table and these percent's are the same on all normal curve tables.

IQ scores use normal distributions scores.

We know that the intelligent testing scores in Wechsler and Binet [pronounced as be-nay], the mean of 100 and the calculated standard deviation is 15 points. We can plot those on a normal curve figure and get a sense of what percentage of the population has scores between certain values and put 100 in the middle representing the mean.

At the first standard deviation marker, I’ve added 15, as the calculated standard deviation of 15 from the mean of 100 . Now I have 115 here add 15 more. And at this point two stand deviation units above the mean.

I have 130 add 15 more points and I get 145 that corresponds to three standard deviations above the mean. And then on the other side I subtract 15 from 100 to get one standard deviation unit below the mean representing the score of 85, subtracting 15 more here gets 70. Subtracting 15 more here at this point is 55.

Now I can talk about what percentage of the people have scores between these values. For example between 100 and 115 is 34 percent of the population. Or I could talk about between 85 and 115 is 68 percent, 34 plus 34, 68 percent of the scores, IQ scores are between 85 and 115.

Now back to our previous example of those 25 test scores.

Remember I said the mean was 85 and the calculated standard deviation was 10. I plot 85 in the middle. I add 10 subtract 10. So I add 10 to the mean and I put 95 right here one standard deviation above the mean, subtract 10 from 85 and gets 75 and I'm plotting that at one standard deviation unit below the mean. So in my 25 test scores, 68 percent of the scores are between 75 and 95.
(This is feedback for the knowledge check) – no audio

Now we are at the last part of this lecture, let’s visit the topics of validity and reliability. Validity refers to how well an instrument measures what it intends to measure. Reliability refers to the degree to which an instrument produces stable and consistent results.

Validity is a judgment about the appropriateness of a measure for specific inferences, interpretations, or conclusions that result from the scores of findings.

It’s the inference that’s valid or invalid, not the measure. For example, most achievement tests were not designed to measure teacher effectiveness. The use of them for this purpose has a low level of validity.

Measurement validity is a matter of degree and is not an “all-or-none” proposition. Both investigators and consumers of research need to judge the degree of validity that is present, based on available evidence.

For example, one way to strengthen the validity of an instrument (say questionnaire) of teacher’s practice of classroom assessment is to ask roughly 15 teachers to review the items for clarity and completeness of covering most, if not all, assessment and grading practices used in the classroom.

We can also invite experts in the field to review the assessment items to strengthen the validity.

This is called content-related evidence for validity.

Measurement Reliability is the extent to which participants, rater, and observer scores are free from error. We want to know if a measure consistently gives the same scores.

Many factors contribute to error, both random and systematic. Sometimes the questions may be ambiguous. Students might be tired, sick, or hungry. Testing sessions might be interrupted by power outage, etc. There are many ways to check reliability.

For example, a stability estimate of reliability involves administering the same instrument to the same group of people with a reasonable interval, say a few weeks between the first and second tests. The correlation of the two sets of scores is then calculated. This is also called test-retest reliability. It is important to establish reliability before the research is undertaken, as well as during the study.

In this video, we have reviewed:

• Scale of measurement

• Different types of frequency distribution

• Central tendency in context

• Measurement validity and reliability

Please consult with your instructor or textbook if there are points not clear to you.
